articles.headline: Democrats Make Hillary Clinton a Historic Nominee
articles.snippet: The party is looking to move beyond lingering anger and unite behind the first woman to represent a major American political party in a presidential election.
articles.abstract: The party is looking to move beyond lingering anger and unite behind the first woman to represent a major American political party in a presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Democratic convention formally nominated Hillary Clinton for president on Tuesday, making history by choosing a woman to be the first standard-bearer of a major political party, a breakthrough underscored by a deeply personal speech by Bill Clinton calling her “the best darn change-maker I have ever known.”
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Why Home Solar Panels No Longer Pay in Some States
articles.snippet: Utility regulators are upending the financial dynamics of residential solar as they try to meet their obligations to customers who don’t have roof panels.
articles.abstract: Utility regulators are upending the financial dynamics of residential solar as they try to meet their obligations to customers who don’t have roof panels.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAFAYETTE, Calif. — It was only two years ago that Elroy Holtmann spent about $20,000 on a home solar array to help cover the costs of charging his new electric car. With the savings on his monthly electric bills, he figured the investment would pay for itself in about a dozen years.

articles.headline: A Worry if Hillary Clinton Wins: What to Do With Bill
articles.snippet: Clinton aides are addressing a potentially thorny problem: Historically, when Mr. Clinton has time on his hands, he can create dangerous distractions for his wife.
articles.abstract: Clinton aides are addressing a potentially thorny problem: Historically, when Mr. Clinton has time on his hands, he can create dangerous distractions for his wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.

articles.headline: Marissa Mayer’s Media Problem at Yahoo Is Now Verizon’s to Solve
articles.snippet: Before she led Yahoo, while still at Google, Ms. Mayer spoke of the difficulties for media companies of capitalizing on their own content.
articles.abstract: Before she led Yahoo, while still at Google, Ms. Mayer spoke of the difficulties for media companies of capitalizing on their own content.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the end, the deal that Yahoo announced on Monday, that Verizon Communications would buy its internet business for $4.8 billion, looked more like an escape than an exit. Yahoo, once at the center of the consumer web, had been pushed to the margins, overwhelmed by direct competition and generational change.

articles.headline: Apple’s iPhone Sales Drop Again, but Services Are a Bright Spot
articles.snippet: A second quarter of dismal sales leaves analysts wondering: Are customers out of love with Apple, or just waiting for the latest products?
articles.abstract: A second quarter of dismal sales leaves analysts wondering: Are customers out of love with Apple, or just waiting for the latest products?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Have consumers lost their affection for Apple gadgets, or are they just waiting for the new iPhones to come out in September?

articles.headline: At World’s Largest Hedge Fund, Sex, Fear and Video Surveillance
articles.snippet: One employee’s complaint, as well as interviews with people who have worked for Bridgewater, describe an atmosphere of surveillance that silences those who don’t fit the mold.
articles.abstract: One employee’s complaint, as well as interviews with people who have worked for Bridgewater, describe an atmosphere of surveillance that silences those who don’t fit the mold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ray Dalio, the billionaire founder of the world’s largest hedge fund, Bridgewater Associates, likes to say that one of his firm’s core operating principles is “radical transparency” when it comes to airing employee grievances and concerns.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Spy Agency Consensus Grows That Russia Hacked D.N.C.
articles.snippet: American intelligence agencies cautioned that they are uncertain whether the breach was an effort to manipulate the 2016 presidential election.
articles.abstract: American intelligence agencies cautioned that they are uncertain whether the breach was an effort to manipulate the 2016 presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence agencies have told the White House they now have “high confidence” that the Russian government was behind the theft of emails and documents from the Democratic National Committee, according to federal officials who have been briefed on the evidence.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton, a Reluctant Star of Her Own Prime-Time Show
articles.snippet: Naturally guarded, Mrs. Clinton has seemed a reluctant star of her prime-time production at the Democratic National Convention.
articles.abstract: Naturally guarded, Mrs. Clinton has seemed a reluctant star of her prime-time production at the Democratic National Convention.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Follow along for our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.

articles.headline: The Same Healthy Food, but It’s Cheaper Across Town
articles.snippet: In South Los Angeles, the price of a meal at Everytable restaurant will be about half as much as it is at a second location downtown.
articles.abstract: In South Los Angeles, the price of a meal at Everytable restaurant will be about half as much as it is at a second location downtown.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a new restaurant called Everytable opens on Saturday in the poverty-stricken area of Los Angeles known as South L.A., a grab-and-go Jamaican jerk chicken bowl with coconut rice, beans, plantains and carrots will be the most expensive meal on the menu at $4.50.

articles.headline: How Companies Like Dollar Shave Club Are Reshaping the Retail Landscape
articles.snippet: Dollar Shave Club, recently acquired for $1 billion, typifies online-only companies that have upended traditional models of stores and advertising.
articles.abstract: Dollar Shave Club, recently acquired for $1 billion, typifies online-only companies that have upended traditional models of stores and advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world might be a mess, but look on the bright side: Men’s shaving products are much better than they used to be.

articles.headline: All Charges Dropped Against Baltimore Officers in Freddie Gray Case
articles.snippet: The prosecutor secured not a single conviction against six officers charged. But she offered a passionate defense of her decision to pursue the case.
articles.abstract: The prosecutor secured not a single conviction against six officers charged. But she offered a passionate defense of her decision to pursue the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The state’s attorney here dropped all remaining charges Wednesday against three city police officers awaiting trial in the death of Freddie Gray, closing the book on one of the most closely watched police prosecutions in the nation without a single conviction — and few answers about precisely how the young man died.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Jess Bidgood

articles.headline: Donald Trump Calls on Russia to Find Hillary Clinton’s Missing Emails
articles.snippet: “Russia, if you’re listening, I hope you’re able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing,” Mr. Trump said, essentially encouraging a foreign power’s cyberspying.
articles.abstract: “Russia, if you’re listening, I hope you’re able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing,” Mr. Trump said, essentially encouraging a foreign power’s cyberspying.
articles.lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that he hoped Russian intelligence services had successfully hacked Hillary Clinton’s email, and encouraged them to publish whatever they may have stolen, essentially urging a foreign adversary to conduct cyberespionage against a former secretary of state.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and David E. Sanger
